title: Mourners farewell drowned teen
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website media_camera Family and friends wore T-shirts honouring Tui as well as traditional dress at the funeral of Tuipulotu ‘Tui’ Gallaher. Picture: John Appleyard Tui Gallaher: Hundreds turn out at funeral for teen who drowned at Maroubra SHAYA LAUGHLIN, The Daily Telegraph January 5, 2017 1:01pm 
HUNDREDS of mourners came together to pay their respects for teenager Tuipulotu Gallaher, who drowned at Maroubra Beach last week. 
Many of the 14-year-old’s friends and family are wearing a shirt with the words “Tears for Tui”, as they farewelled the teen during a service at Waterway Chapel at Rookwood Cemetery. 
Others are dressed in traditional Tongan outfits, including the boy’s father Soane. media_camera The order of service for the funeral drowning victim Tuipulotu Soane Gallaher, 
Tui’s mother Sandra Tomano said if her son was at the funeral he would tell her to “stop crying”. 
“He did everything for me ... and his family,” she said in tears. 
“My family has been there for Tui since day one, how can I repay you all. 
“I don’t know what to do, I have nothing to give — all I have is my heart. 
“It’s not goodbye, it’s good night.” 
Reverend Tim Booker from Guildford Anglican Church — where Tui and his family attended regularly — said the teenager had a beautiful “gentleness”. 
“Not many teenagers have that,” he told a chapel full of tearful mourners. 
“Also unique among teenage boys, he was tidy and organised. 
“What a unifying young man he was.” media_camera Family and friends wore T-shirts honouring Tui as they openly shed tears at the loss of the 14-year-old. Picture: John Appleyard 
Tui’s father Soane Gallaher, who lives in New Zealand, also spoke at the teenager’s funeral. 
“Today is a happy day,” he said. 
“Tui is in a good place.” media_camera Mourners wore shirts bearing ‘Tears for Tui’ to the funeral of the 14-year-old who drowned at South Maroubra Beach. Picture: John Appleyard media_camera Tui's mother Sandra Tomano speaks at the funeral of her son. Picture: John Appleyard 
On Tuesday December 27, Tui was swimming with a friend at night when they got into trouble at the south end of the beach. 
A member of the public spotted the boys in distress and managed to pull the friend to safety. But when he went back for Tui he had disappeared. 
A full scale air and sea search was carried out for several days before surfers spotted Tui’s body in the sea about 100m out from shore. media_camera Tui's mother Sandra touches Tui's coffin as it is taken for burial. Picture: John Appleyard 
His was one of a spate of drowning deaths in pools and waterways over the festive period prompting calls for a government campaign to raise awareness for water safety. Body recovered on Maroubra beach 0:42 
A body has reportedly washed ashore on Maroubra Beach near where a teenager went missing on Tuesday. December 30th 2016
